data.title: Nice way to spend an hour
data.text: We were in Fort Collins for a wedding weekend and had all day Saturday to ourselves. After a long walk down Mountain Ave (beautiful neighborhood) we doubled back to check out The Avery House. Nicely restored historic home, but the best part was learning about the Avery family...little peek back in time. An hour is plenty of time to allow.

data.title: Excellent place to visiy
data.text:
Happened to be in Ft. Collins. Marsha K was the docent. Excellent 
tour. She is very knowledgeable. We
enjoyed the tour very much; if you visit Ft Collins, definitely visit Avery
House to learn about the history of Ft Collins and see the beautiful home and its antiques.

data.title: Classic FC
data.text: This house and the house behind it bring back lots of memories. Family friends lived there in the 60s.

data.title: Fascinating tour, seeing how people lived over 100 years ago
data.text: This is a well-maintained home from the turn of the 19th to 20th centuries. Much of the furnishings are original. The house itslef is beautiful inside and out. Guided tours are given, one group at a time. The guide we had was very knowlegeable. There are no phontos allowed inside. This is for very good reasons, if you are curious then ask them why. The living and dining rooms were ornate (at least compared to several of the smaller homes in the area). The two areas in which I was most impressed were the kitchen and the children's room. It is well worth the visit. Go some weekend and ride the trolley from either City Park or the Catholic Cathedral. It is about 1/4th the way from the Cathedral to City Park. Enjoy the tour.

data.title: 1879 Victorian House of City Founder Franklin Avery
data.text: Open year around on weekends, 1pm to 4pm. Stopped by for a tour. Volunteer staff is excellent and knowledgeable. Period furnishings are good and the place will give you a better understanding of times of the past. Yard is beautiful in the summer and sometimes you'll see a wedding on the lawn. A good stop for history lovers.

data.title: Stepping Back in Time!
data.text: Went with a friend. Enjoyed the old house & knowledgeable tour guide. Hearing the history of the house & it's contents was exciting. They even have the diary of a child who lived in the house, hearing the story of how the diary was found was amazing. Love the old architecture.

data.title: A story of  wonderful history in Colorado
data.text: I squeezed in a tour of the Avery House, as I had limited time in Fort Collins and as I walk many places, I walked to the Avery House from 'Old Town Square', and at a brisk walk it may have taking about ten minutes to get there.  The Avery House is wonderful, the architecture is fantastic, the furniture and history, quite educational.  However, one of the loveliest parts of my tour was the docent, 'Karol'.  I remember her saying my name is Karol with a 'K'.  Lovely, lovely lady, in historic attire and I informed her from the 'get go' that my time was limited, yet she managed to give me a very good and dense in information tour and I so appreciated it.  I did not have currency in smaller amounts of one dollar bills, as the donation is $3.00, so 'Karol' was kind to offer me the currency she had on hand.  My donation resulted a bit higher than the $3.00, and was worth every penny, to see the yesteryear fashions displayed and 'Karol' speak of so much, including the special Japanese art of wallpaper the Mr. Avery had ordered for the family home décor.  The home is a must see for American history, for historic fashion, architecture, décor and more! Do visit!

data.title: Just a nice old house
data.text: When touring the Colorado State Campus, you drive through many residential neighborhoods.  This house while nice, is not a worthwhile stop.

data.title: Interesting Architecture and History
data.text: We visited with some friends during the pre-Christmas holiday period when parts of the house were decorated. This was nice as were the permanent fixtures, most of which are original to the house.  And learning some of the family history from the period-costumed docent was interesting as well.  The Avery family was truly very prominent in the history of Fort Collins.  But what I found most interesting was the architecture of a house that was expanded several times in its history.  If you look closely you can see this, but it was done very carefully and tastefully such that the whole cohesive result is quite appealing in a "frontier" town.

data.title: Christmas open house is great!
data.text: A charming historic Fort Collins residence, with numerous original furniture pieces.  Knowledgeable docents and no wait time, even for open house.  Christmas decorations were wonderful, quaint and memorable.  Harks back to a simpler time.

data.title: A stunning example of a Victorian home!
data.text: I am a native of England and I know Victoriana and history. This house is amazing. One is greeted at the door by a costumed docent who conducts private tours. Entry is free but there is a suggested contribution of $3 per person. The house is fully furnished and decorated. Many of the items belonged to the original Avery family and others are appropriate to the era. Our guide was knowledgable and amusing and patient with all our questions. I have rarely seen a historic house so well-kept and furnished. The wallpapers are reproductions but true to the time and in some cases reproduced exactly. The woodwork is stunning and in looking around the house, one gets a very definite feel for life at the time it was built. All the rooms, from the kitchen to the bedrooms to the bathrooms are furnished and staged and one is able to enter each room and not just look at it from behind a rope. It truly is a must-see for visitors to Fort Collins.

data.title: Fort Collins House Museum
data.text: The Avery House is a well maintained museum adjacent to downtown Fort Collins.  Built in 1879 the stone house features gables, towers and dormers for an unusual mix of architectural features.  Furnished with period pieces and staffed by very knowledgeable volunteers.  Across the street from a stop on the old trolley line.

data.title: Fort Collins History
data.text: I was amazed at the knowledge the volunteer that gave us a tour of the home. Everyone one in the home was very nice.  The family history was very interesting.  If you are in Fort Collins, this is a neat spot to visit.

data.title: Labor of Love
data.text: Small and very well done period home maintained and staffed by volunteers. Furniture and decor are wonderful.  Currently also doing a clothing exhibit that is not that great and distracts from the tour.

data.title: Photography is not allowed
data.text: I was looking forward to touring one of Fort Collins' historic sites. Unfortunately they don't allow photography inside the Avery House because there are so many thieves in town. I think they have an inaccurate opinion of Fort Collins residents, but they can do what they want since they own the building. I will just have to find historic sites that are open to the public.

data.title: Wonderful
data.text: Beautiful house, knowledgeable volunteers and well done tea parties once maybe twice a year. I have been to two High Teas at the house and on 12 tours, taking friends. I learn more each time about the history of Fort Collins. I have never has a bad thought on any visit.

data.title: Avery history
data.text: 1879 was an exciting time in the USA and Fort Collins, and Franklin Avery and his home here in Fort Collins was right in the middle of the excitement and growth of the West. Great architectural details, good docents to lend a flair to the telling, a fun way to learn history and get a glimpse of life at the turn of the century.

data.title: Pretty Cool
data.text: This is a very cool little house. You can see lots of very old things and the guides are very well informed. The thing that bothered me was that the guides kept yelling at people for brushing up against chairs and stuff, exclaiming they were old. The house was cool, but the guides were a bit dramatic about touching.

data.title: Interesting History
data.text: The docent, Eric, was a gem of information. While photos of the interior of the house are not permitted (seems some folks take pictures so they can come back later and steal the items), he was gracious enough to allow us photos of architectural elements. Fascinating history to the house, and great workmanship. Personal guided tour is a must!

data.title: A great house museum in Northern Colorado
data.text: Volunteers do a stellar job offering tours at the historic Avery House. The house is really a fairy-tale (modest) mansion in Old Town and has been lovingly restored.
